author: Renanll

text: My all-time favorite is Donkey Kong Country 2: Diddy's Kong Quest from SNES, the greatest console of all time. The music (David Wise is my favorite video game composer), level design, atmosphere, gameplay, difficulty curve and bosses, all pure gold. I like how they changed the tone from lighthearted to a way darker tone. Rescuing Donkey Kong as a plot-point was something I preferred over the first one's get back all the bananas. So much nostalgia value too. I've played so many games during these years and though I'm mostly a fan of Japanese video game culture (J-RPGs, Visual Novels etc), my favorite game of all time is still non-Japanese. I'm glad I have a unique choice like that.

author: Mateo Uzcategui

text:
Ocarina of Time for me.  I still to this day consider it my first *real*  zelda game, only messing around with zelda 1 as a 5 yr old and beating one dungeon.  It was my first real 3-d adventure and boy was it memorable.... I mean I could and have gone on for hours about that game.  Memorable (as with many games others mention) is such an understatement.

However, I need to shoutout Mother 3 (Earthbound 2) as a great runner-up, best story in any game period for me, such a deep philosophy.

text:
On the Fire Emblem department, you should begin by trying Sacred Stones on the GBA. Hardcore fans hate it because it goes kinda easy on you, and it allows you to level grind a lot, which is a moot point IMO, 'cause if you play right you don't really need to.

The other GBA american FE game is harder, but actually pretty manageable too.
author: ViciousOS

text:
Mother series isn't by Nintendo.
It's by Ape and HAL Laboratory.
Sure they've only developed games for Nintendo, but it means that the Mother games aren't first party titles.
/nerd

Chrono Trigger rocks.

author: bushwhacker2k

text: I know how you feel. The best music from this game, FFVI, and Secret of Mana makes me pine for the days when Square wasn't Square-Enix and they knew how to make likable games. I think that there have been strong RPGs since the SNES-era, especially during the PS1 era when Chrono Trigger got its unusual-but-charming sequel and Xenogears came out. The PS2 era (I'm playing through some of these lately) is more of a mixed bag, and the games feel somewhat less inspired despite being pretty good.

author: yungjosie

text:
I'll suggest you try it out, and since the source code is public, the game is considered abandonware, and you can easily find it for free, and it's not considered illegal either. The main story is already great (some really, really epic moments) and there are a bunch of mods you can throw on it to add replayability.

Also the SCP, Source Code Project, improves the graphics, so that they now look excellent even by today's standards.

author: SupraDarky

text:
My favourite game ever, sadly, isn't very popular.

It's Freespace 2. A space-sim that was released almost ten years ago, the game got insanely good reviews, but was a commercial flop. It's the only game I'd ever give a 10/10 too. And since the developers knew the game was a commercial failure, they actually released the source code to let the community improve it. So basically it's 11/10 material now.

A close second would be Lufia 2. I love that game, and replay it often, it's just awesome.
